newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Creative sees audio sales rise.
newsitem.headline: Creative sees audio sales rise.

text.p: Multimedia company Creative Technology Ltd said on Saturday it saw revenue from its audio products continuing to grow.

"Our audio revenue has been growing from about over 30 percent to right now over 50 percent. We see this trend will still be able to continue," Sim Wong Hoo, Creative's chairman said at a news briefing.
Creative is known for its SoundBlaster range of sound cards.
Sim, who is also chief executive officer, said Creative had taken the lead, set new standards and broke new grounds in all five generations of its products since the first 8-bit soundcard in 1991.
Its latest AWE64 soundcard was Creative's largest revenue generator in its fourth quarter ended June 30, 1997. For that quarter it recorded earnings of US$51.2 million on sales of $280 million.
For the full year ended June 30, 1997, it posted record net profit of $167 million on sales of $1.23 billion.
Audio products made up 56 percent of revenue for 1996/1997, upgrade kits 34 percent and 10 percent came from other products.
Sim said Creative aimed to replace the 40 million installed base of sound cards and 20 million of clone cards with its AWE64 in 1997-1999.
Going forward, Creative is working on an "environmental" sound chip which all enable users to hear authentic sounds from instruments played on World music.
It was looking to the original equipment market (OEM) moving towards audio products based on the latest PCI bus standards in the first half of 1998.
Creative is selling its Emu8008 PCI sound chip that goes on a motherboard to OEMs.
Another area Creative was pushing aggressively into was in DVD (digital video disk).
Creative last week launched it next generation PC-DVD kit which includes a decoder card and high performance DVD ROM drive for US$379.99.
Sim said the focal point this Christmas would be on DVD where the company would first focus on the U.S. market.
The company expects unit sales in its PC-DVD kit to reach six-digit this Christmas, he said.
He believed DVD drives would replace CD-ROM drives by the end of 1998.
On its geographical markets, vice president Michael Sulllican said Europe would be a challenge in the first quarter but was expected to pick up later on.
He said Creative would be introducing a programme in Europe in October to encourage users to upgrade their old sound cards to the new AWE64.
He said Creative had substantial market share in Europe ranging from more then 60 percent in Germany and France and exceeding 90 percent for some countries.
Creative has said when it released its fourth quarter results that it expected the first quarter to be flat.
But for the full year 1997/1998 it expected to achieve its projected 10-15 percent revenue growth and gross margins of 30 percent.
On plans for its cash of $417.9 million, Sim said the company was looking at making more strategic acquisitions.
-- Singapore newsroom (65-8703080)
